entry.title: Re: Confifg：Determine Requirement Type by Item category C...
entry.content:
Hello  @ISoma 

Thanks for the screenshot.

SAP will not alter the mapping in Determine Requirement Type by Item Category SSCUI 105120 for TAN within a single tenant. Since this content is delivered and locked in Public Cloud, neither an incident nor an expert configuration will unlock it.

What you can currently do is supported.

Drive the requirement type from master data

    • Set Strategy Group / MRP Type in the product master.
    • Standard determination then picks the requirement type/class from the material’s planning strategy (this overrides the generic TAN fallback).

Use an alternative item category were allowed

    • If your scope allows, establish a Y* item category and assign it through item-category determination to the appropriate scenarios...
    • You still cannot edit 105120, but you can pair the Y-category with materials or schedule lines that produce the requirement type you need.

Model the business need via the schedule line and  planning strategy

    • Select MTS versus MTO behaviour through material planning settings so the system determines the correct requirements logic without tenant-specific changes.

Product change request (longer term)

    • If you need a different standard mapping for TAN, submit it via SAP Continuous Influence, as SAP does not supply one-off tenant mapping adjustments.

If you specify the exact behaviour you want, such as MTO for product X, no MRP reduction, or specific ATP logic, I’ll propose a concrete combination of Strategy Group/MRP Type and  item/schedule line that achieves it without modifying 105120.

SAP Document References

  • SAP Help Portal - Central Business Configuration:
  • SAP Community - Clean Core Strategy:
  • SAP Help Portal - Item Category Determination:

entry.title: Re: SAC save data analyzer
entry.content:
@egil63 

Data Analyzer is a perfect option for adhoc data Analysis for an end user. 

  • If you are assigned to the creator or admin role, you can save an insight in the public or your private files.

  • If you are assigned to a viewer role, you can save an insight in your private files only. To do this an administrator can grant the private insight privilege to users with no create rights on the public or private files by creating a custom role and assigning the private insight privilege. With the private insight privilege, these users can also share and delete their insights however they can't edit or rename the insight in the file repository. For more information on creating custom roles, please see Create Roles.

  • You can save an insight to any workspace that you have access to

For permissions Refer to below.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/00f68c2e08b941f081002fd3691d86a7/93fec5646f144e109745ce74fd492c3f.html#object-type-permissions

Nikhil

entry.title: How to use key-user in-app Custom Logic extensibility to change eDocument currency in SAP Cloud ERP
entry.content:
Introduction

Some countries (like Colombia) might required to have reports sent to fiscal authority on their local currency even if the transaction was executed in a different currency and is registered on the system in a foreign currency. On  SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition this requirement might be delivered in some localizations via extensibility as a localization as a Self-service to be implemented during implementation project.

Below example, shows how a sale in USD would be reported without the extensibility (left) and with extensibility solution (right):

Solution through Extensibility 

Based on a demand for Colombia invoice eDocument, we have developed the KBA 3648968.

On the KBA, we instruct how to find extension points (BAdIs) to change information in eDocument generated via eDocument Cockpit or Manage Electronic Documents apps. We also highlight that for each localization, it should be consulted the SAP Help Portal documentation for that localization to check which extension points are available and which should be used.

We also provide a proof-of-concept sample code that shows how the change for a XML file created for an eDocument for Colombia can be changed. Note that each localization and eDocument likely will have different extension points and limitation as well as each implementation might have its own requirements that will result on complete different code.

So each implementation should develop its own code and the KBA code is only an example and do not cover all scenarios nor is a final solution to be implemented.

Important Assets

The following documentation might be helpful to obtain more detailed information:
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition:

    • SAP KBA 2805847 - eDocument Colombia Troubleshooting Guide (Topic B103)
    • SAP KBA 3648968 - Currency issues and Extensibility in Colombia eDocuments - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
    • SAP KBA 2974488 - Calculation errors in CUFE
    • SAP Help Portal:  Colombia App Extensibility
    • SAP Help Portal: Country/Region-Specific Functions
    • SAP Help Portal: Creating Implementations

This content was brought to you by the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Customer Care Team

entry.title: Re: UIGEF001 maps in S4HANA 2023
entry.content:
Hi Elang234, 

Here's the answer in detail why we cannot support UIGEF001 in future release.

The SAP Geo Framework applications in component UIGEF001 are supported until S/4HANA 2021, with conditions.

New applications were created in S/4HANA 2021 in the default UI component UIS4HOP1 and are the preferred applications, with UIGEF001 applications only being used by existing customers during cutover from UIGEF001 to UIS4HOP1. Some customers may need time to migrate customer extensions to the new apps while running on an upgraded S/4HANA release. All these applications are based on the 3.x Esri JavaScript API.

In S/4HANA 2022 FPS1  SAP introduced new applications based on the Esri 4.x JavaScript API and will be the future Esri API platform for the Geo Framework. It is strongly suggested that customers move to these applications by S/4HANA 2023. Both 3.x and 4.x applications may be run in parallel during cutover. In a future release of S/4HANA the applications based on the 3.x API will be deprecated as Esri support for this API is ended. Here is the latest GEF Administration guide to follow.

Installation:

Follow the appropriate Master Guide for your implementation

  • 2383937 - SAP Geographical Enablement Framework - Installation & Upgrade Information Master Note (UIGEF001)
  • 3149622 - SAP Geographical Enablement Framework - Installation & Upgrade Information Master Note (UIS4HOP1)

It is strongly suggested that all UI support packages be implemented and subsequent notes applied to ensure correct functionality.

Ensure the applicable note for your UI component are implemented to avoid incorrect time entries when editing geometry.

  • 3409341 - [GEFUI] : Utilities UTC End Date Assignment Function Issue
  • 3419897 - [S4GEF] GEF_DATE_TO is populating with incorrect UTC format

Review note 2878649 - HANA Update to 1909 Fix for Data Type Date Fields Update. This will ensure your initial configuration is correct after an SAP BASIS level change.

Fully implement and test the base Geo Framework sample implementation before implementing EAM content.

  • Activate Business Function FND_GEF.
  • Ensure switch dependent BC sets are correctly activated. It may be some items are not fully activated due to system/client settings preventing the automated activation. Should this happen you will need to manually activate the dependent BC set for the switch.

After successfully testing the default configuration activate the EAM Business function.

  • Activate Business Function LOG_EAM_GEF.
  • Ensure switch dependent BC sets are correctly activated and manually activate if required.

Complete configuration for Database Connection as per online documentation. You should now have a basic working system to test.

Implementation:

Best practice suggests tables for each Business Object. This ensures the latest table deign and optimizations are in place. Implementation is performed using the following steps.

  • Using transaction GEF_CRT_TAB create tables for each of the EAM business objects. It is suggested to use a short prefix such as “Notif” for Notifications. A suffix is not required and the SRID can be included if desired.
  • Update the configuration for each Business Object to point to the relevant table/view prefix, remember to include the “.” At the end. For example “Notif_3857.”
  • Should you wish to also use System level tables for non-EAM objects it is suggested to create new tables with the most current design using the same transaction, for example “SysGeom_3857.” . Update configuration for system configuration.

Because SAP does not know how a customer will translate their assets to map objects the delivered EAM configuration is an example of how EAM objects can be geo enabled. This configuration should be treated as an example and used as a guide for own implementations.

It is suggested that the most complex Geo Object be configured first and then used as a copy template for other Geo Objects. It is much easier to delete unwanted entries from the copy than manually add content, and then change the template configuration to suit each individual object.

Thanks,
Nick.

entry.title: Re: Issue in Fiori App Mass Maintenance of Bills of Mater...
entry.content:
Hi @nitin_desai_c79 

Thank you for your question.

The error you are experiencing means that the maximum threshold for simulation is being read as 0, even though you have maintained the control parameter in customizing.

To resolve the error, here is what you should check:

  1. Check your Business Role Authorization
    • Ensure the user has the correct Business Catalog assigned. For example, SAP_BOM_MASS_MAINT_PC or equivalent. Please note, if authorizations are incomplete, the system may not pick up the maintained threshold.
  2. Control Parameters for BoM (SSCUI / App)
    • In SSCUI 102543, the control parameters for Bill of Material, check that the parameter Maximum No. of BOMs for Mass Changes is indeed set to 1000.
    • Also confirm that this configuration is assigned to the correct plant/application area.
  3. Re-publish Settings
    • After updating the SSCUI, ensure you publish and re-test the app. Sometimes cached parameters are not picked up until a new session.

Please note that in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the Simulation step uses a stricter threshold check than execution. If the threshold is not picked up, the system defaults to 0.

Mass Maintenance of Bills of Material Items

I hope this provides the desired result. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA - Map Format Data App - Conversion functi...
entry.content:
Hello @craigsnell 

Thanks for the question and the screenshot.

There is no official or complete descriptive index with examples covering all types of conversion functions. In the Map Format Data app. The list you see comes from the long-standing DMEE/DMEEX conversion function catalogue; Map Format Data reuses that library in S/4HANA Cloud.

SAP’s help covers how to use the app, but does not document each of the 400 functions one by one. SAP Help Portal   SAP Community

What you should do (recommendation)

  • App help/learning unit for the end-to-end process and where conversions fit. SAP Help Portal-Map Format Data for Payments  SAP Learning
  • The legacy DMEE catalogue serves as a reference for function semantics codes like CL, CR, C0, etc., such as left/right justification, excluding/replacing characters, and adding leading zeros. It is not specific to Cloud, but the meanings are consistent Carry over. LeanX Analytics

Practical tips

In the selection dialogue, use the search box to type words like left-justified, replace, exclude, leading zeros, date, etc., which quickly narrows down the list.

Build a sandbox mapping and test with sample data; save your picks as a template so your team reuses the same functions.

If you truly need an in-app index with examples, log it on SAP Continuous Influence; there’s no API or export of the catalogue in Public Cloud today.

Let me know if you need further support

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: SAP PS - AUC Settlement issue
entry.content:
Dear Shubham 

Have you tried the following steps?

A. Review and Correct the Investment Profile

Navigate to the Investment Profile (via OITA or WBS control tab).

Ensure the "Manage AUC" indicator is set.

Confirm that the Investment Profile is assigned to the correct Asset Class (one meant for automatic AUC creation; typically 4001 or its copy).

B. Ensure WBS Is Configured Properly

In transaction CJ20N, open the WBS element.

Under the Control Data tab:

Confirm that the Investment Profile is correctly assigned.

The WBS element should be of type AUC.

When properly configured, releasing the WBS will automatically generate the AUC and link it appropriately.


Release the WBS to trigger the correct AUC creation with a valid origin link.

C. If Incorrect AUC Already Exists

Delete the Investment Profile from the WBS:

This action should delete the incorrectly created AUC.

Reassign the correct Investment Profile.

Release the WBS again to generate a new, correctly linked AUC.

 

D. Check Asset (AUC) Origin Tab

In the Asset master’s Origin tab, verify that the WBS element appears in the correct field (instead of a PR number).

If it's still wrong, confirm that your configuration edits are saved and that system statuses are active.

 

Best regards

entry.title: Re: F3567 Maintenance costs analysis is not available in...
entry.content:
Hello @joezuehlcke11 

App F3567 Actual Maintenance Cost Analysis is visible in the SAP Fiori Apps Library but it is not directly assigned to any standard Enterprise Asset Management scope item. That is why you don’t see it in your activated scope.

Here is how you can activate it and make it available:

  1. You need to check your Business Catalog Assignment. In Public Cloud, apps are enabled via Business Catalogs, not scope items alone. For F3567, check the catalog SAP_EAM_BC_MAINTPLN_ANALYTIC_PC or similar depending on release. Assign this catalog to a business role for your Maintenance Planner.
  2. Verify Business Role Template. To do this, use the Business Role Template SAP_BR_MAINTENANCE_PLANNER. Then add the catalog for Actual Maintenance Cost Analysis if not already included.
  3. Note that no Separate Activation Needed. Since this is a Fiori analytical app (powered by CDS views), there is no additional configuration or activation required in Public Cloud. Once the correct role/catalog is assigned, the app becomes visible.

I hope this provides the desired result. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: From Reactive to Preventative: SAP Support’s Next Chapter
entry.content:
Digital transformation raises the stakes for performance and uptime. That’s why SAP support is evolving from fast issue resolution to proactive prevention - powered by automation and agentic AI.

Watch the video to see how we combine always-on monitoring, intelligent risk detection, and expert guidance to keep your business running smoothly.

What’s changing and why it matters:

  • Automated agents continuously scan SAP environments to spot misconfigurations, incorrect usage, or emerging risks.
  • Machine learning predicts peak demand and flags potential bottlenecks before they impact users.
  • Identified risks are turned into actionable “risk objects,” categorized, and routed to the right mitigation path.
  • Non-critical issues can be auto-mitigated by AI, while customers or partners are engaged when action is required.
  • For complex or critical situations, SAP support experts step in with hands-on guidance.

This preventative strategy isn’t theory - it’s proven. With round-the-clock control room support, real-time monitoring, and proactive risk management, SAP Commerce Cloud achieved 100% uptime during the most demanding events of the year: Black Friday and Cyber Monday.

Our commitment remains the same: deliver exceptional support, earn your trust, and drive meaningful business impact through continuous improvement. AI helps us detect and predict; our experts help you resolve and optimize. Together, we turn insights into a seamless customer experience.

Press play to learn how SAP Support brings innovation and reliability together - so you can move faster with confidence.

entry.title: SAP Solution Extension (SolEx) partner solution - Top 10 reasons for SAP Customers
entry.content:
Here are 10 customer-facing advantages of choosing an SAP Solution Extension (SolEx) partner solution:

  1. Single contract and invoice with SAP
    You buy the solution from SAP under SAP’s standard commercial framework (often on the SAP price list/SAP Store). This simplifies procurement, vendor onboarding, legal review, and renewals, and can align with your existing SAP agreements (e.g., co-termination, enterprise/RISE constructs)

  2. One support channel via SAP
    Incidents are opened through SAP’s Support Launchpad and handled under SAP’s coordinated support model, with seamless transfer to the partner’s experts when needed. You get “one face to the customer” for issue resolution, SLAs, and escalation.

  3. Jointly aligned roadmap and release management
    SAP and the partner coordinate roadmaps so the solution remains compatible with current and upcoming SAP releases (e.g., S/4HANA, BTP). This de-risks upgrades and ensures timely support for new SAP features.

  4. Assured integration and quality
    SolEx solutions undergo SAP qualification/certification, architecture reviews, and integration testing. You benefit from pre-validated integrations, reference architectures, and lower implementation risk.

  5. Upgrade safety and lifecycle assurance
    The partner and SAP align maintenance windows, APIs, and dependency management. This reduces regression issues during SAP upgrades or transformations (e.g., to S/4HANA or RISE with SAP).

  6. Faster time-to-value
    Prebuilt content, best practices, and accelerators—often packaged specifically for SAP landscapes—shorten implementation time and reduce customization effort.

  7. Security, compliance, and operational rigor
    Solutions are reviewed against SAP’s security and quality baselines. You gain documented controls, audit-ready artifacts, and confidence in performance, security, and data protection alignment.

  8. Global reach and consistent delivery
    SAP’s global sales and support coverage means access to multilingual support, regional expertise, and consistent delivery standards across countries and business units.

  9. Commercial predictability and lower TCO
    Consolidated contracting and support reduce vendor sprawl and integration costs. Predictable maintenance, co-termed renewals, and standardized metrics help control total cost of ownership.

  10. Joint governance and escalation
    You can leverage coordinated governance (e.g., executive sponsorship, steering committees, Q-gates) across SAP and the partner. Escalations are streamlined with clear ownership and accountability.

entry.title: Re: Maintenance Planning for SAP Integration
entry.content:
Hi @Gilberto_Onesti 

In SAP Integration Suite (CPI) there is no annual maintenance calendar app like in SAP S/4HANA Maintenance Management. Instead do the following.

  1. Planned Maintenance Windows for CPI
    • SAP publishes planned maintenance schedules for Integration Suite tenants via the SAP Trust Center
    • There, you can filter for your region and service (Cloud Integration / Integration Suite) to see planned downtime or maintenance events.
  2. For customer notifications, any upcoming maintenance that affects your tenant is communicated through the SAP for Me portal (System Notifications) or via email notifications if you are registered as a contact.
  3. The annual calendar concept exists in S/4HANA Cloud Maintenance Management (for technical objects, orders, etc.). In Integration Suite, you only have planned maintenance announcements, not a configurable annual calendar in the system itself.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Unable to Print Terms & Conditions in Multiple Languages
entry.content:
Dear SAP,

We are unable to arrange printing of Terms & Conditions (T&C) in multiple languages on Customer Invoice output forms in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. T&C text was maintained in Manage Texts / Manage Logos apps in EN, DE, and FR.

 

In the output form (Adobe form), only the EN text prints correctly. Other language versions (DE, FR) are not being picked, or when they do, the formatting is lost.

 

Expected: System should pick the T&C text in the output language of the billing document, similar to how logos are determined via Manage Logos app. All maintained languages should print correctly in customer-facing forms.

 

Actual: Only EN version prints properly. For other languages, text is either missing or formatting is broken.

 

Business Impact: Legal T&C cannot be delivered to customers in their local language, which is a compliance and customer communication issue.

 

So requesting your help to please confirm if multi-language T&C printing via Manage Texts/Manage Logos apps is supported. Provide resolution or guidance on how to correctly arrange T&C texts per language in output forms. 

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Unable to Print Terms & Conditions in Multiple Languages
entry.content:
In the current release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the Manage Texts app allows maintaining text entries in several languages. However, unlike logos, the system does not automatically pick up the maintained translations into the billing output form. The printing of multi language T&Cs requires that the custom form template explicitly binds the corresponding text objects for each language version.

In your case, the English text appears correctly, while the DE/FR versions are not being rendered. This indicates that the form template (Adobe LiveCycle Designer) is only retrieving the EN text. The formatting issues you observed are also typically related to the text field setup in the template. 

I'd recommend you to reviewing your custom form template and adjusting the text field binding so it dynamically picks up the text according to the language of the billing document, and also ensuring that the text fields are set to support formatted (rich) text in Adobe LiveCycle Designer. 

Here are the list of KBAs and SAP Help Portal documentation to guide you: 

  • 0002679030 - Extensibility for Billing Document Printout - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • How to Extend a Custom Form Template for Billing Output with Custom Fields
  • Extensibility for Output Forms and Email Templates of Billing Documents
  • 0003251818 - Displaying Amount and Currency in Form Templates - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (same scenario is similar with currency/amount)
  • 2984817 - Form design in Adobe LiveCycle Designer
  • Adobe Help - Formatting field values and using patterns
  • SAP Help Portal - Form Templates - Locales
  • Setting Up Output Management (1LQ)

entry.title: Let’s Talk About Clean Core
entry.content:
What is Clean Core?

In simple terms: Clean Core is the practice of keeping the core of SAP S/4HANA as “clean” and standardized as possible.

This means avoiding heavy customizations directly in the system core and, instead, using extensions, APIs, and official tools provided by SAP. By doing so, your company can:

  • Upgrade the system with less effort.

  • Reduce maintenance costs.

  • Adopt innovations much faster.

👉 More details here: SAP Clean Core Methodology

Why is this important?

In SAP ECC, it was common for companies to change the central code to meet specific needs. The result? A heavy, rigid system — expensive to upgrade and always slowing down the move to the cloud.

Clean Core was born to break this cycle. It allows your company to take advantage of SAP’s continuous updates without the “headaches,” while staying agile enough to innovate.

A Simple Analogy: Tidying Up the House

Think about it like this:

  • If you organize your house the way Marie Kondo suggests — everything in its place — it’s much easier to keep order every day.

  • But if you only tidy up when guests arrive, you’ll spend way more time and energy, and probably still leave things out of place.

Clean Core works the same way: you keep the system organized from the start, instead of “fixing things” only when a new upgrade or version migration arrives.

So, Where Should You Customize?

Here’s the strategic insight: not everything needs customization.

Accounting reports, tax invoices, legal requirements… these are standardized and can follow SAP’s market-ready models, especially in the Cloud Public Edition.

That frees up time and budget for what really matters: the processes that differentiate your business and make customers choose you.

And it’s there — in these unique areas — that you should apply business intelligence and customizations, using the right S/4HANA tools (such as in-app extensions or side-by-side developments on SAP BTP).

In Summary

Clean Core is more than a technical recommendation. It’s a system management philosophy:

  • Keep what is standard truly standard.

  • Customize only where your competitive advantage lies.

  • Always think about why your company exists and the value it delivers to customers.

That way, every update will be smooth, every innovation easier to adopt, and the company’s focus will remain on what creates real market impact.

entry.title: Re: List Prices from Microsoft Excel Not Working As Expected
entry.content:
Hello,

This is the correct behavior for List Prices, the button will always download a fresh template so you can edit and then send it back to the system. To be able to add a new List Price on system using Microsoft Excel is necessary to install the Add-In for Microsoft Excel, and then upload using the Save data to button. For this you can follow the below steps:

Firstly, install the SAP Add-In for Microsoft Excel by following the below steps:

Go to the Application and User Management work center.
Enter the Download Center view.
Click on the download icon for SAP Add-In for Microsoft Excel.
After the download, execute the installer on your machine.
Once the installation is successfully completed, a new tab SAP BUSINESS BYDESIGN will be available in the excel workbook. 

Follow the below steps to Import List Prices via Excel:

Open the Microsoft Excel workbook.
Go to the tab SAP BUSINESS BYDESIGN and log into the desired system using the Logon option available. Enter the tenant URL, Username and password to login. 
Go to Product Portfolio work center and navigate to List prices view.
Click on New and choose the option List prices from Microsoft Excel. 
This will download the template for importing the List prices in the Excel. 
Open the downloaded template in Microsoft Excel.
Enter all the relevant details.
Go to SAP BUSINESS BYDESIGN tab and click on the option Save data to. 
This will successfully import the List prices data into the system. 
Navigate to UI to check the List price details. 
Hope this clarifies your questions.

In case you have any further questions or issues, please reach out to me and I'll be glad to help. Otherwise please complete the incident and reply to our SAP Support Satisfaction Survey and share with me what you enjoyed the most about the experience you had with my work. 
Once you complete the incident, you will be redirected to the survey and this will help me to always deliver a great support. 

Thanks, 
Diéssica 
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: calculating depreciatio in SAP SAC Advance formula
entry.content: Can you try below once :

entry.title: Re: calculating depreciatio in SAP SAC Advance formula
entry.content: try below once :

entry.title: Re: calculating depreciatio in SAP SAC Advance formula
entry.content:
Try as below 

// Limit to the 2-year budget horizon
MEMBERSET [d/Time] = [d/Time].[2025.JAN:2026.DEC]

// Loop over each Asset
FOREACH [d/Asset]

  // Get values from measures
  DATA(cost)       = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures].[AssetCost]);
  DATA(lifeYears)  = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures].[UsefulLife]);   // years
  DATA(endDateIdx) = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures].[EndDateIdx]);   // YYYYMM number

  // Skip if no cost or no life
  IF (cost = 0 OR lifeYears = 0)
    CONTINUE;
  ENDIF;

  // Convert useful life in years → months
  DATA(lifeMonths) = lifeYears * 12;

  // First month of depreciation = asset end date + 1
  DATA(depStart) = endDateIdx + 1;

  // Last month by useful life
  DATA(depEndByLife) = depStart + lifeMonths - 1;

  // Last month allowed by budget (Dec 2026 = 202612)
  DATA(budgetEnd) = 202612;

  // Take the earlier of life end vs budget end
  DATA(depEnd) = depEndByLife;
  IF (depEnd > budgetEnd)
    depEnd = budgetEnd;
  ENDIF;

  // Monthly depreciation amount
  DATA(monthDep) = cost / lifeMonths;

  // Now loop through time periods and post depreciation
  FOREACH [d/Time]
    // Read the MonthIndex of this time period
    DATA(curIdx) = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures].[MonthIndex]);

    // Post depreciation only if within range
    IF (curIdx >= depStart AND curIdx <= depEnd)
      RESULT([d/Measures].[Depreciation]) = monthDep;
    ENDIF;

  ENDFOR;

ENDFOR;

entry.title: Deployed CAP+Fiori App is running, but UI gives 404 on metadata call and is not visible in Work Zone
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I'm developing a full-stack application in SAP Business Application Studio and I'm facing a final issue after a seemingly successful deployment to Cloud Foundry.

My Project Setup:

  • Backend: SAP CAP with Node.js

  • Database: SAP HANA Cloud, using synonyms to access tables from another container.

  • Frontend: SAP Fiori Elements (List Report Object Page template).

  • Security: Using a standard XSUAA service.

  • Deployment Target: The final goal is to integrate the app into our SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition.

The Problem / Observed Behavior: The deployment to Cloud Foundry using cf deploy completes 100% successfully. In the CF space, I can see that my applications (-srv, -ui) are in the "Started" state, and the -db-deployer is "Stopped", which is the expected behavior.

The issue is that the application is unreachable and invisible to end-users:

  1. When I access the direct URL of the CAP backend service (...-srv.cfapps...), I correctly see the CAP welcome page listing my service endpoint at /odata/v4/catalog. This confirms the backend is alive and serving the correct path.

  2. However, when I access the main UI application URL (...-ui.cfapps...), the page title loads, but the rest of the page is blank.

  3. Checking the browser's developer console, I see a 404 (Not Found) error when the application tries to fetch the service metadata. The failing request is: GET .../odata/v4/catalog/$metadata.

  4. Consequently, the application does not appear in the Content Explorer of the SAP Build Work Zone after refreshing the "HTML5 Apps" content provider.

My Question: What could be the reason for the 404 Not Found error during the metadata call from the UI, given that the deployment is successful and the backend service is confirmed to be running and serving the correct path? It seems there is a routing or communication issue between the AppRouter (-ui app) and the CAP service (-srv app) that I am unable to diagnose further.

Relevant Configuration Files attached

entry.title: Re: which products are linked to the SAP RISE license (cl...
entry.content:
Hello @davi3 

RISE with SAP is sold as a subscription bundle, so the license covers more than just the S/4HANA system. The exact components depend on whether you’re using SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition or Private Edition, but in both cases, you get a package of core products and services:

SAP S/4HANA Core

  • Public Edition → SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (multi-tenant SaaS) with scope items delivered as standard.
  • Private Edition → SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (single-tenant) based on the full S/4HANA stack, offering greater flexibility for custom code and extensions.

Infrastructure and Technical Services

  • Included hyperscaler infrastructure (AWS, Azure, GCP, or SAP DC).
  • Technical managed services (system provisioning, upgrades, patching, monitoring).

Business Process Intelligence

  • SAP Signavio Process Transformation Suite (process discovery, benchmarking, modelling, and mining).

SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP)

  • Credits for extensions, integrations, and analytics (typically a starter package included with Cloud Platform Enterprise Agreement consumption)
  • Preconfigured integration content (SAP Integration Suite) and extensibility options.

Tools for Migration and Activation

  • SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit and readiness check.
  • SAP Activate methodology, accelerators, and best practices.

Embedded Support & Operations

  • SAP Cloud ALM (Application Lifecycle Management).
  • SAP Enterprise Support, Cloud Edition.
  • SAP Readiness Check, maintenance, and security services.

Key Differences

  • Public Edition → SaaS model, standardised scope, quarterly releases, limited customisation.
  • Private Edition includes the full ERP scope, like on-premises, with annual releases, custom code, and add-ons possible.

Check the references below

  • SAP Help Portal – RISE with SAP Overview
  • SAP Discovery Center – RISE with SAP Services

With RISE, you receive not only S/4HANA licensing but also the infrastructure, BTP credits, Signavio, migration tools, and lifecycle management, all through a single subscription.

Let me know if you need further information

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Parallel Multicast causing random failures in my Message Mapping subprocesses
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I’m working on a very large integration that takes a long time to execute since it has many subprocesses running sequentially with a Sequential Multicast, each performing upserts to SuccessFactors.

To improve performance, I moved some of these subprocesses to a Parallel Multicast so they could run at the same time. This successfully cut the execution time in half, but now I’m occasionally running into random errors in the Message Mappings that don’t seem to make sense.

Some of the errors I’ve seen include:
com.sap.xi.mapping.camel.XiMappingException: A pseudo attribute name is expected.
com.sap.xi.mapping.camel.XiMappingException: Content is not allowed in prolog.
com.sap.xi.mapping.camel.XiMappingException: Premature end of file. (this one happens most often)

The subprocesses are running in parallel like this:



And the ones that tend to fail are the ones that include routers, like this one:



I’ve tried running them in Trace mode and reusing the failing payload in the Message Mapping simulation, and it works fine there. I also re-executed the integration with the exact same data, and it succeeded the second time. It looks like the payload is sometimes breaking randomly, which causes the mapping to fail.

Has anyone run into something similar? Any help would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks,
Agustin

entry.title: Multiple SAP HANA Systems on One Host
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP HANA is an in-memory database that supports mission-critical workloads and is a key component of an SAP system that must be protected from failures. Business-critical production HANA databases require a well-designed and tested High Availability and Disaster Recovery (HA/DR) plan to ensure business continuity and minimize downtimeA primary (active) HANA database can be replicated to a secondary instance using SAP HANA System Replication (HSR). HSR continuously replicates data to an alternate instance to ensure that changes persist in the event of a primary instance failure.

SAP does support running multiple SAP HANA systems (SIDS) on a single production SAP HANA hardware installation (or single virtual machine). 

Multiple SAP HANA systems on one host are also known as Multiple Components on One System (MCOS).

SAP support running multiple SAP HANA systems (SIDs) on a single production SAP HANA host. This is restricted to single-host / scale-up scenarios only.  One Hardware which can be segregated for two HANA tenant installations. Filesystem e can be also be segregated which allows us to do maintenance separately.

Few considerations:

  • RAM:

SAP HANA is memory intensive. Sufficient RAM is crucial for optimal performance, potentially 64GB or 128GB or more depending on the data size and workload.

  • CPU:

Adequate CPU resources are needed to handle the processing demands of multiple HANA instances.

  • Disk Space:

Ensure sufficient disk space for the installation binaries, data volumes, log volumes, and trace files for all instances/tenants.

  • Network:

Plan for network configuration, especially if using a multi-host setup or if the databases need to communicate with other systems.

File System structure:

 

        192.168.1.124:/nasData-1a /hana/data/SID1/mnt00001 nfs4 ...

        192.168.1.128:/nasLog-1b /hana/log/SID1/mnt00001 nfs4 ...

        192.168.1.124:/nasData-2a /hana/data/SID2/mnt00001 nfs4 ...

        192.168.1.128:/nasLog-2b /hana/log/SID2/mnt00001 nfs4 ...

 
 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

FS structure for 2 DB SID’s SDP – is Prod S4 SDS – is for Quality system

 

 

Production support is restricted to SAP HANA 1.0 SPS 09 (and higher) or SAP HANA 2.0 due to the availability of some resource management parameters (for example affinity). Be aware that running multi-SID on one SAP HANA host may impact performance of various types of operations, as contention for computing resources may occur (memory, cpu, i/o, ...).

SAP strongly recommends performing requisite testing in any project before going live; in general, stress/volume testing is recommended in order to provide good indicators of expected performance. When operating a system that features a multi-SID deployment, SAP recommends to actively make use of the resource management features of SAP HANA (e.g. parameters controlling memory limits, and influencing utilization of CPU cores, etc.) in order to optimize performance.

Business critical Production HANA DB’s require a well designed and tested High Availability and Disaster Recovery (HA/DR) for business continuity and allow a SAP technical team to minimize the downtime and increase the application availability during planned and unplanned outages. SAP HANA is an in-memory database that supports mission critical workloads and is a key component of an SAP system that needs to be safeguarded from failures. A primary or active HANA database can be replicated to a secondary instance using SAP HANA System Replication (HSR).

SAP HSR continuously replicates data to ensure that in the event of a failure on the primary instance, changes persist in an alternate instance. In Public Clouds the secondary HANA database instance can either exist within the same region (different Availability Zone) or in a separate region.

 

 

 

SAP systems that are critical to business continuity require a well designed and tested High Availability and Disaster Recovery (HA/DR) framework to maximise application availability during planned and unplanned outages. SAP HANA is an in-memory database that supports mission critical workloads and is a key component of an SAP system that needs to be safeguarded from failures. A primary or active HANA database can be replicated to a secondary instance using SAP HANA System Replication (HSR). SAP HSR continuously replicates data to ensure that in the event of a failure on the primary instance, changes persist in an alternate instance.

To achieve a near zero Recovery Time Objective (RTO), it is necessary for the primary and secondary HANA database instances to have a similar memory capacity. However, if a higher RTO is acceptable, it is possible to operate the secondary HANA database instance with a reduced memory footprint. This can result in considerable cost savings for compute, either by choosing a smaller instance size or leveraging excess memory on the secondary to operate other SAP HANA database workloads.

The reduced memory requirement in the secondary HANA node is achieved by configuring the secondary to not load HANA column data into main memory. A restart is required before promoting it to be primary, at which time it is assumed that the full memory requirement is available. The actual memory demand on secondary host is highly dependent on the HANA System Replication (HSR) configuration and production data change rate. Even by disabling HANA column table loading, the memory demands on the secondary host can go beyond 60% of the actual production HANA memory usage. If the secondary instance is not sized correctly, this can lead to out-of-memory crashes and reduced resilience.

This blog aims at providing a detailed guidance on how to size the secondary HANA database instance while operating with reduced memory footprint with examples for multiple deployment scenarios.

Architecture

There are two common architectures for deploying a secondary HANA database with a lean, or reduced memory footprint in single Hardware.  In this blog we differentiate between them with the terms ‘smaller secondary’ and ‘shared secondary’. Smaller secondary is where the infrastructure is sized smaller than the primary, and then re-sized on takeover. This is sometimes referred to as Pilot Light DR as in the blog Rapidly recover mission-critical systems in a disaster. Shared secondary is where the unused memory is utilized by a non-production or sacrificial instance. SLES documentation refers to this as ‘Cost Optimized Scenario‘.

In both these scenarios, preload of column tables is disabled on the secondary HANA database. The specific configuration to implement this change is to set the HANA database parameter preload_column_tables to false. This configuration needs to be changed to ‘true’ before promoting this instance as primary. Given the manual intervention required and the time taken following a takeover to load the column tables before the HANA database is open for SQL connections, these scenarios are more relevant for a Disaster Recovery (DR) than a High Availability (HA) solution.

Shared secondary

A common use case for a shared secondary scenario is to operate an active quality (QAS) instance along with the secondary HANA database instance on the same host, also called MCOS (Multiple Components One System). This setup requires additional storage to operate the additional instance(s). During a takeover, the instance with lower priority (QAS) can be shutdown to make the underlying host resources available for production workloads.

 

 

For both the scenarios, the secondary HANA database instance configuration is set to preload_column_tables = false. The default value of this parameter is ‘true’ and has to be explicitly changed on the secondary instance to operate with reduced memory. This change is made in HANA database configuration file (global.ini) located in the file path (/hana/shared/<SID>/global/hdb/custom/config).

HANA SR Operation modes

The two operation modes supported by HANA System Replication (HSR) to setup a secondary system are logreplay and delta_datashipping. A high-level comparison between logreplay and delta_datashipping operation modes is presented below.

SAP HANA System Replication Operation Modes

#

Criteria

logreplay

delta_datashipping

1

Operational Behavior

Logs are shipped and continuously applied on the secondary system.

Delta data is shipped from the primary to the secondary occasionally (default 10 min). Logs are only shipped, not applied, until a takeover.

2

Recovery Time

Shorter takeover window, as logs are applied continuously until a failure occurs.

Relatively higher takeover time.

3

Data Transfer Needs

Only logs are shipped, resulting in comparatively lower data transfer needs.

Transfer of both delta data and logs adds to higher data transfers.

4

Network Bandwidth

Due to reduced data transfers, this mode requires relatively lower bandwidth between sites.

This mode requires higher bandwidth between sites.

5

Memory Footprint on DR Instance

Significantly higher memory is required as the column store needs to be loaded for faster delta merge.

The memory footprint is much smaller because the column store isn't loaded into the main memory when column preload is disabled.

6

Multi-tier Replication

Supported

Supported

7

Multi-target Replication

Supported

Not supported

8

Secondary Time Travel

Supported

Not supported

 

 

It is worth noting that in a 3-Tier replication setup, a mix of operation modes is not supported. For example if the primary and secondary HANA database instances are configured to use logreplay for HSR, then delta_datashipping operation mode cannot be used between the secondary and tertiary systems and vice-versa.

SAP Guidance on disabling column preload

The actual memory usage on the secondary host is dependent on the HANA replication operation mode configuration and the preload setting for column tables. Hence it is important to understand the sizing requirements for different operation modes in a HANA System Replication setup. The below chart is an excerpt from SAP Note : 1999880 – FAQ: SAP HANA System Replication (SAP Support Portal login required)

 

As per the above guidance, even with preload = off, the minimum memory requirements for operation mode ‘logreplay’ also factors in the column store memory size of tables with modifications . As a rule of thumb, consider the size of column store tables with data modified in the previous 30 days from current date of evaluation.

SAP Note 1969700 – SQL Statement Collection for SAP HANA provides a collection of SQL scripts that can be used for analysing various administration and performance aspects of SAP HANA database. With minor changes to one of the scripts from this collection, titled ‘HANA_Tables_ColumnStore_Columns_LastTouchTime’, it is possible to provide a rough estimate for the minimum memory required to accommodate these tables. For exact steps of executing this script, refer to the ‘Additional information’ section at the end of this blog.

In the following sections, the examples provide details on how to evaluate sizing when deployed in a Shared secondary scenario. Although not shown, a similar sizing exercise is applicable to the Smaller secondary scenario, without the additional considerations of running a second HANA database instance (for example QAS) on the same host.

Option 1 – HSR with Operation Mode: logreplay

In the following example, the primary and secondary production HANA database instances are deployed on two 9TiB High Memory instances. The secondary instance host also hosts a Quality Assurance (QAS) HANA Database Instance. To be able to deploy these instances, the global_allocation_limit for all the three HANA database instances (PRD-Primary, PRD-Secondary, QAS) needs to be evaluated. Following section illustrates how to derive these values.

 

 

 

In the subsequent sections, Global Allocation Limit is referred as ‘GAL’.

  • GAL for Primary instance

On the Primary instance, global_allocation_limit is not set in this example (default value=0 and unit is MB). A default value does not limit the amount of physical memory that can be used by the database. However, as per the SAP Note 1681092 – Multiple SAP HANA systems (SIDs) on the same underlying server(s), maximum allocation to HANA database by operating system follows the rule of 90% of the first 64 GB of available physical memory on the host plus 97% of remaining physical memory.

  • GAL for Secondary instance

SAP’s guidance for minimum memory requirements for secondary HANA database instance with preload=off and logreplay operation mode is, ‘Row store size + Column store memory size of tables with modifications + 50 GB’. As an example, on the primary instance, the SQL script ‘HANA_Tables_ColumnStore_Columns_LastTouchTime’ was executed and the column tables with modifications for the previous 30 days is identified as 3077 GB. For detailed steps of executing this script, refer to the ‘Additional information’ section of this blog.

 

 

Similarly, using SQL script ‘HANA_Memory_Overview’ from SAP Note 1969700 – SQL Statement Collection for SAP HANA, the memory requirements for ‘Row store’ can be determined. An example value of 153 GB is considered for the following evaluation.

Memory required (min) = Row store size

                        + Column store memory size of tables with modifications

                        + 50 GB

Ex: (153 + 3077 + 50) GB = 3280 GB

GAL for DR = 3280 GB^

  ^Convert to MB before changing GAL in the system

Note: This value provides the minimum sizing guidance only. It is recommended to allocate additional headroom of 10-20% of this value to accommodate any immediate spike in column store table modifications.

Similarly, global_allocation_limit (GAL) has to be set for the second HANA database instance (QAS) running on the DR site. According to  the SAP Note 1681092 – Multiple SAP HANA systems (SIDs) on the same underlying server(s), the sum total of all HANA database allocation limits on a particular host should not exceed 90% of first 64 GB of available physical memory on the host plus 97% of remaining physical memory.

Σ [(GAL_DR) + (GAL_QAS)] ≤ {(0.9 * 64) + [0.97 * (Phys Mem GB - 64)]}

Applying this guidance to our example of 9 TiB(9896 GB)  bare metal instance is as follows.

Σ [(GAL_DR) + (GAL_QAS)]  ≤  {[0.9 * 64] + [0.97 * (9896 - 64)]} GB

                          ≤  9595 GB

The total available memory for all HANA database instances is 9595 GB, while the total available physical memory on the bare metal instance is 9TiB (9896 GB). As the HANA DR instance memory sizing is derived at 3280 GB, the remaining size can be the maximum allocatable memory for QAS instance.

Σ [ (GAL_DR) + (GAL_QAS)]  ≤ 9595 GB

Σ [ 3280 GB  + (GAL_QAS)]  ≤ 9595 GB

GAL for QAS: The maximum allowed value for GAL_QAS = 6314 GB^

    ^Convert to MB before changing GAL in the system

Option 2 – HSR with Operation Mode: delta_datashipping

This section provides an overview of HANA System Replication deployed with ‘delta_datashipping’ operation mode and the procedure to evaluate the memory sizing for each individual instance.

 

 

 

  • GAL for Secondary instance

 

SAP’s guidance for minimum memory requirements for secondary HANA database instance with preload=off and delta_datashipping operation mode is as follows. Applying this guidance to our example scenario to derive GAL for DR is as follows

Max [64 GB, (Row store size + 20 GB)]

Applying this guidance to our example scenario to derive GAL for DR is as follows

Max [64 GB, (153 + 20 GB)]

GAL for DR: The minimum required value for GAL_DR = 173 GB^

    ^Convert to MB before changing GAL in the system

The total available memory for all HANA database instances is 9595 GB, while the total available physical memory on the bare metal instance is 9TiB (9896 GB). In the previous step, secondary HANA database instance memory sizing is derived at 173 GB, the remaining size on the host can be the maximum allocatable memory for QAS instance.

Σ [ (GAL_DR) + (GAL_QAS)]   ≤ 9595 GB

Σ [ 173 GB   + (GAL_QAS)] ≤  9595 GB

GAL for QAS: The maximum allowed value for GAL_QAS = 9422 GB^

   ^Convert to MB before changing GAL in the system

Conclusion

This blog highlights that the cost savings of deploying a secondary HANA database instance with a reduced memory footprint may not be realized with logreplay operation mode. This is because of the higher memory demands of column store being loaded into the main memory of secondary HANA database and occurs irrespective of the column table preload setting. This behavior is by design for continuous log replay. In addition, there is a requirement to constantly monitor column store data growth on the primary and adapt memory allocations on the secondary to avoid out-of-memory (OOM) issues on secondary. The operation mode delta_datashipping facilitates better cost savings in comparison to logreplay while disabling the preload of column tables on secondary HANA database instance. However, this choice comes with limitations which may include a higher recovery time and an increased demand for network bandwidth between the replication sites.

Opting for delta_datashipping is usually a trade-off between cost considerations and other limitations of this operation mode as explained in this blog. With relaxed RTO requirements and higher network bandwidth between the replication sites, the use of ‘delta_datashipping’ can be promoted. Also, with larger database instances, the potential for cost savings is higher. This is because the memory footprint on the secondary has a minimum requirement of row store memory and buffer requirements even for smaller database instances. The association between various factors that influence the choice of a particular operation mode and the potential for cost benefits with delta_datashipping option are represented in the following diagram. These factors are independent of each other and can individually influence the ability to use ‘delta_datashipping’ and thereby the cost benefits.

It is also important to understand that the memory requirement calculation for the secondary and subsequent setting of global_allocation_limit, is an iterative process. As the production database size grows, eventually the column store demand for delta merge also grows on the secondary instance. Hence, the memory allocations of secondary and optionally, other HANA database instances provisioned on the same hardware should be monitored periodically and also after mass data loads, go-lives and SAP system specific life-cycle events.

Additional Information

Following are the steps to execute the SAP SQL script.

  1. Download the file SQLStatements.zip which is an attachment to SAP Note 1969700 – SQL Statement Collection for SAP HANA
  2. Unzip the file and identify the SQL script named HANA_Tables_ColumnStore_Columns_LastTouchTime_2.00.x+.txt (for HANA 1.0, choose a different version of the same script).
  3. Modify the script with the following two changes.

TOUCH_TYPE

  Identify the section with title ' /* Modification section */'

  Identify the parameter 'TOUCH_TYPE' and enter the value as 'MODIFY'

Ex: 'MODIFY' TOUCH_TYPE,       /* ACCESS, SELECT, MODIFY */

BEGIN_TIME

  Identify the section with title ' /* Modification section */'

  Identify the parameter 'BEGIN_TIME' and key in the value as 'C-D30'

Ex: 'C-D30' BEGIN_TIME,

  1. Execute the script on the HANA Production tenant DB using any of the SQL editors of SAP HANA Cockpit, SAP HANA Studio and DBACOCKPIT or the tool hdbsql.
  2. Identify the output under the column ‘MEM_GB’ for the column store size that has been modified in the previous 30 days from the date of script execution.

entry.title: S/4HANA CDS View with CDC enabled
entry.content:
Hello!

I have a question regarding CDC logging tables being shared by both SLT and ODP subscribers.

Currently we are testing this functionality in QA system and the changes are captured as expected.

One issue we see is that same Subscriber logging table is being consumed by both SLT and ODP subscribers and I would like to know if this is a normal behaviour.

Our QA system had a copy of Production recently and it shows the subscribers from Prod of SLT sharing the same logging table as the ODP subscriber. Because of this, the logging tables are getting piled up and not cleaned up automatically after the records are consumed by target system via CDS View. The SLT subscribers were present before the CDS view was created.

Will this be a problem when we deploy this CDS view and subscription in production?

In every article around and even SAP has mentioned that the Subscriber logging tables are unique per subscriber but it doesn’t seem so with what we see in QA.

If that’s the case shouldn’t there be a new logging table for CDS view when the CDS subscription was created?

Highly appreciate your response in this! Thank you.

entry.title: Re: Sharing SAP HANA Cloud instance to multiple subaccounts and creating HDI containers
entry.content:
Hi @ankurbabu 

Yes, the "hana (hdi-shared)" entitlement is required in any Cloud Foundry subaccount where you want to share your HANA Cloud instance.

I tried creating a new subaccount in my trial account today, and noticed that this entitlement is not automatically assigned.
To enable it, please go to your global account and manually assign the entitlement to the relevant subaccounts.
